comment_text.mn145:1.1: This sutta recurs at SN 35.88, with slight differences in the opening and closing. In addition to two discourse parallels in Chinese, the popularity of this narrative is attested by its appearance in later texts such as the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya and the Divyāvadāna, as well as in artworks (see Anālayo, Comparative Study, vol. ii, p. 828).
comment_text.mn145:1.3: This Puṇṇa is to be distinguished from the Koliyan ascetic of MN 57 and the son of Mantāṇī of MN 23. His only other appearance is his Theragāthā verse at Thag 1.70.
comment_text.mn145:2.1: The idea of a “retreat” as understood today was popularized in the 20th century. In early times, it seems, when an individual monastic felt they were ready, they would approach the teacher seeking advice for their retreat.
comment_text.mn145:5.2: The commentary says that Puṇṇa was in fact born in Sunāparanta, specifically the trading port of Suppāraka, which is modern Nallasopara north of Mumbai on India’s west coast. Sunāparanta is otherwise known as Aparanta (“Far West”, Bv 29:17.2). Puṇṇa’s choice was far-sighted, as from the time of Ashoka, Suppāraka became a major trading center with ports in India and lands west as far as Mesopotamia, Egypt, Eastern Africa, and Rome. A fabulous tale of such trading voyages is told in Ja 463.
comment_text.mn145:5.32: This is in reference to the notorious story of Migalaṇḍika in Bu Pj 3, told more briefly in SN 54.9. Several monks, meditating improperly on the unattractiveness of the body, sought suicide as the way out. In response, the Buddha taught mindfulness of breathing, which is “peaceful and sublime, a deliciously pleasant meditation”. | The idiomatic phrase satthahāraka is difficult. The obvious reading is to take sattha as “knife”, the meaning it has in the preceding sentence. However, that yields the sense “knife-bringer”, “assassin”, whereas the use of idaṁ in MN 145:5.32 shows it must be neuter, i.e. it is a thing not a person. Richard Gombrich suggests we read sattha here as equivalent to Sanskrit śvasita, “breathing, life” (see Brahmali’s note on Bu Pj 3:2.49.1), yielding the sense “life-taker”, “breath-stealer”, “deadly weapon”. This agrees with the Vinaya commentary, which explains, “What does it take? Life.” (Kiṃ harati? Jīvitaṁ). Since this idiom is only used in the context of suicide, I call it “suicide weapon”, and the verbal form “commit suicide”.
comment_text.mn145:7.5: The parallel passage at SN 35.88:18.7, says rather that he passed away in that same rainy season.

root_text.mn145:1.3: Atha kho āyasmā puṇṇo sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā puṇṇo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:

root_text.mn145:5.2: “Imināhaṁ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena ovādena ovadito, atthi sunāparanto nāma janapado, tatthāhaṁ viharissāmī”ti.

root_text.mn145:6.2: Sakkhissasi kho tvaṁ, puṇṇa, iminā damūpasamena samannāgato sunāparantasmiṁ janapade viharituṁ.
root_text.mn145:7.1: Atha kho āyasmā puṇṇo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā senāsanaṁ saṁsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena sunāparanto janapado tena cārikaṁ pakkāmi.
root_text.mn145:7.2: Anupubbena cārikaṁ caramāno yena sunāparanto janapado tadavasari.
root_text.mn145:7.3: Tatra sudaṁ āyasmā puṇṇo sunāparantasmiṁ janapade viharati.
root_text.mn145:7.4: Atha kho āyasmā puṇṇo tenevantaravassena pañcamattāni upāsakasatāni paṭivedesi, tenevantaravassena pañcamattāni upāsikasatāni paṭivedesi, tenevantaravassena tisso vijjā sacchākāsi.
root_text.mn145:7.5: Atha kho āyasmā puṇṇo aparena samayena parinibbāyi.
root_text.mn145:8.1: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn145:8.2: “yo so, bhante, puṇṇo nāma kulaputto bhagavatā saṅkhittena ovādena ovadito so kālaṅkato.
root_text.mn145:8.4: “Paṇḍito, bhikkhave, puṇṇo kulaputto paccapādi dhammassānudhammaṁ, na ca maṁ dhammādhikaraṇaṁ viheṭhesi.
root_text.mn145:8.7: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn145:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn145:1.3: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Puṇṇa came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn145:2.1: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
translation_text.mn145:2.2: “Well then, Puṇṇa, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn145:3.1: “Puṇṇa, there are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn145:3.2: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,
translation_text.mn145:3.4: Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say.
translation_text.mn145:3.5: There are sounds known by the ear …
translation_text.mn145:3.9: ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn145:3.10: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,
translation_text.mn145:3.12: Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say.

translation_text.mn145:4.2: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them,
translation_text.mn145:4.4: When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say.

translation_text.mn145:4.12: When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say.
translation_text.mn145:5.1: Puṇṇa, now that I’ve given you this brief advice, what country will you live in?”
translation_text.mn145:5.2: “Sir, there’s a country named Sunāparanta. I shall live there.”
translation_text.mn145:5.3: “The people of Sunāparanta are wild and rough, Puṇṇa.
translation_text.mn145:5.5: If they abuse and insult you, what will you think of them?”
translation_text.mn145:5.6: “If they abuse and insult me, I will think:
translation_text.mn145:5.7: ‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t hit me with their fists.’
translation_text.mn145:5.8: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
translation_text.mn145:5.9: That’s what I’ll think, Holy One.”
translation_text.mn145:5.10: “But if they do hit you with their fists, what will you think of them then?”
translation_text.mn145:5.11: “If they hit me with their fists, I’ll think:
translation_text.mn145:5.12: ‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t throw stones at me.’
translation_text.mn145:5.13: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
translation_text.mn145:5.14: That’s what I’ll think, Holy One.”
translation_text.mn145:5.15: “But if they do throw stones at you, what will you think of them then?”
translation_text.mn145:5.16: “If they throw stones at me, I’ll think:
translation_text.mn145:5.17: ‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t beat me with a club.’
translation_text.mn145:5.18: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
translation_text.mn145:5.19: That’s what I’ll think, Holy One.”
translation_text.mn145:5.20: “But if they do beat you with a club, what will you think of them then?”
translation_text.mn145:5.21: “If they beat me with a club, I’ll think:
translation_text.mn145:5.22: ‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t stab me with a knife.’
translation_text.mn145:5.23: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
translation_text.mn145:5.24: That’s what I’ll think, Holy One.”
translation_text.mn145:5.25: “But if they do stab you with a knife, what will you think of them then?”
translation_text.mn145:5.26: “If they stab me with a knife, I’ll think:
translation_text.mn145:5.27: ‘These people of Sunāparanta are gracious, truly gracious, since they don’t take my life with a sharp knife.’
translation_text.mn145:5.28: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
translation_text.mn145:5.29: That’s what I’ll think, Holy One.”
translation_text.mn145:5.30: “But if they do take your life with a sharp knife, what will you think of them then?”
translation_text.mn145:5.31: “If they take my life with a sharp knife, I’ll think:
translation_text.mn145:5.32: ‘There are disciples of the Buddha who looked for a suicide weapon because they were horrified, repelled, and disgusted with the body and with life. And I have found this without looking!’
translation_text.mn145:5.33: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
translation_text.mn145:5.34: That’s what I’ll think, Holy One.”
translation_text.mn145:6.2: Having such self-control and peacefulness, you will be quite capable of living in Sunāparanta.
translation_text.mn145:6.3: Now, Puṇṇa, go at your convenience.”
translation_text.mn145:7.1: And then Puṇṇa welcomed and agreed with the Buddha’s words. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Sunāparanta.
translation_text.mn145:7.2: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Sunāparanta,
translation_text.mn145:7.4: Within that rainy season he confirmed around five hundred male and five hundred female lay followers. And within that same rainy season he realized the three knowledges.
translation_text.mn145:7.5: Some time later he became fully extinguished.
translation_text.mn145:8.1: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.mn145:8.2: “Sir, the gentleman named Puṇṇa, who was advised in brief by the Buddha, has passed away.
translation_text.mn145:8.3: Where has he been reborn in his next life?”
translation_text.mn145:8.4: “Mendicants, Puṇṇa was astute. He practiced in line with the teaching, and did not trouble me about the teachings.
translation_text.mn145:8.6: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn145:8.7: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
